item.title: Blog: Launching the CIS Platform Engineering Chapter
item.description:
Platform Engineering Chapter

The platform engineering chapter in CIS aims to enable customers to build and operate platforms on hybrid cloud environments. In order to succeed in this, the skills and culture need to be developed and integrated into the way that engineers at Capgemini deliver service.

Chapter

The chapter is focusing on developing the attitude and priciples essential to successful platform engineering teams’ ways of working.

The original Spotify paper in 2012, described the underlying concept of chapters:

Chapters: Henrik Kniberg & Anders Ivarsson, Spotify 2012

A key tenant though is Aligned Autonomy

The Platform Engineering Chapter is therefore focusing on CIS SME’s and Architects, working closing with the rest of Capgemini, to identify and develop the skills and capabilities required to be able to deliver the best platforms for customers.

Capgemini and our customers have a multitude of platform engineering teams, with the knowledge and experience captured within different business units, and knowledge repositories. The Chapter is also looking to facilitate the sharing and awareness of these.

Platform Engineering

As organisations migrate their IT workloads to various types of public, private and hybrid clouds, platform teams have evolved. A core focus of all organisations is to enable the application (or ‘product’) teams to be more efficient and effective, delivering quality business features quicker. Tjhere are a multitude of views in how that efficiency could be achieved, such as the papter from Peter Seibel or the description from ThoughtWorks

Whereby the platform team will develop accelerators and stacks to provide environments that support the application and data engineering team

Growth & Development

In order to achive this the Chapter is looking to

  • Develop skills
  • Develop accelerators for platform deployments and operation

The training programes and accelerators to deliver on this capability is captured throughout this site.

item.title: Blog: How we got started with the CIS PE Chapter - v0.1
item.description:
This is a generated static site

The first website I hand-crafted with Notepad was a static web site. Painfully static. Made slightly less painful with version control and helper bash scripts. I was an early convert to web content management systems with WYSIWYG editors such as Drupal & Wordpress. Until I had to run them at scale.

This site is built using Hugo, a general-purpose website framework written in Go. Technically speaking, Hugo is a static site generator. Unlike systems that dynamically build a page with each visitor request, Hugo builds pages when you create or update your content.

Show the thing

The content is written in markdown, stored in a git repo in Azure DevOps and published using a release pipeline.

steps:
- script: git submodule update --init --recursive
  displayName: 'Update git submodules'

- script: npm install
  displayName: 'npm install'

- script: |
    wget https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/releases/download/v0.67.0/hugo_extended_0.67.0_Linux-64bit.deb
    sudo dpkg -i hugo_extended_0.67.0_Linux-64bit.deb
  displayName: 'Install Hugo'

- script: |
    hugo
  displayName: 'Hugo build'

- publish: $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/public
  artifact: Public
